content: So, Rust 2021 stable in Rust 1.56? Yes :check:, no :cross_mark:?
cc @nikomatsakis @rylev @Eric Huss
For the added context: we can slip one release and still release in 2021. There doesn't seem to be any good reasons to do so though.
We are still processing crater runs and while it's unlikely (since we've already full processed the 10K most popular crates) there can still be an issue we haven't found yet.
I'm not on T-edition or T-release, but if you ship earlier you get more time in beta in case you missed something, and you'll still have the time to revert in beta if necessary

yeah i doubt we'll run into anything that's so big we would revert stabilization. but we could backport an important fix if really necessary. so far it only looks like small problems with migration lints. and i don't think we should block stabilization on those.
@Joshua Nelson we're on the cusp of beta this week, so there is no time advantage.
Personally, I'm not thrilled about rushing to do PRs. Cargo needs at least 48 hours after 2021 is stabilized, which means it needs to merge today.

I'm not sure I follow: if you don't stabilize in 1.56, it won't be enabled in beta and people won't be able to test it.

Oh, that's a good point about cargo though.
We can stabilize in 1.57, and that means we'd have 12 weeks of beta+nightly to test.
If we merge now, that means we only have 6 weeks of beta time.
we have already tested for quite a while. the public edition 2021 blog post was 21 july
since then it was mostly just migration lints that got updated. nothing big

Eric Huss said:

which means it needs to merge today.

yes, the PR is already waiting. we just need to make the decision and hit r+
Hey folks
hey
I'm catching up
There have been a kind of "steady stream" of small updates to the RFC 2229 rules
Nothing major

But e.g. I think the right fix to https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/88476 is to change the capture rules -- admittedly in a backwards compatible way (strictly preventing errors in Rust 2021 that would otherwise occur)
I don't however understand the point about stabilizing in 1.57 and getting 12 weeks to test
I guess @Eric Huss you mean that if we stabilize shortly after the branch, we have the nightly + beta time?
yea, that's what I meant.
when does 1.57 get released again?
answer: December 2nd 2021 UTC
I definitely think we should stabilize over the next few days, but I'm not sure if it's worth the trouble to hit the 1.56 target or not
i don't think we really need to delay it for anything. all the issues that have popped up are small. if we start today, we'll make it for 1.56 easily. (not if we start wednesday for example.)
place for me to take a few notes: https://hackmd.io/thUMCESvSMqxKDFkjs2ggA
or, maybe I should put that in our google doc
meh, added a link from that to the hackmd, which is easier to edit
What do we need to do to release? @Eric Huss mentioned cargo PRs?
We need to stabilize 2021 on nightly; we need to do some cargo PRs, add'l steps?
I remember @Mara you mentioning there were various bits of documentation to update?
yeah, just tiny things. will send a PR today. just waiting for the edition release decision.

(e.g.

:work_in_progress: The 2021 Edition has not yet been released and hence this section is still "under construction".

in the edition guide)
right, right
so basically: If we stabilize now, we can revisit the decision in beta if we want
I already posted a PR for the edition guide: https://github.com/rust-lang/edition-guide/pull/266

My take is: I don't care to try too hard, but I agree we haven't encountered any sort of blocker, and the sorts of issues we've encountered for closures are small edge cases that could be fixed even on master I believe
Yea, Cargo needs to merge its PR, and then get updated in rust-lang. I'll also need to update the books.
I was thinking of putting in some time to fix up the reference today
And Cargo has to wait for the rustc stabilization to hit nightly.
(as we had discussed Eric elsewhere)
is there a PR for the stabilization?
yes
just waiting to r+ it once we decide
(link?)
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88100
OK

How confident are we that issues we have in the GitHub project are the full extent of known issues and that we're not forgetting something? Do we need to do any sort of issue sweep to make sure we're not forgetting something that wasn't properly labeled or work that wasn't given an issue.
the past few weeks we've tracked all the issues pretty well on the project board
I'm skimming the issues, but I am leaning towards "let's do it"
it gives us a bit more wiggle room for last minute disasters, too :)
I have no qualms with releasing other than the fact that I can imagine us wanting to backport small things like documentation which seems... awkward?
(annoyingly)
we do have to decide
• our policy on backporting docs
• our policy on backporting migrations
I think for the latter we should kind of...not do it
in other words, if we're not comfortable with the current state, let's not ship it
most docs links go to /nightly/ so i don't think we'd really need to backport docs, unless it's something big
in terms of raw numbers, the number of affected crates is believed to be quite small, right?
(from the migration failures)
rustc always ships with lints and suggestions that are not perfect. at this point the edition lints are of high quality and have quite a low number of false positives/negatives.
I wonder why this doesn't work--- oh, I think I know why this doesn't work
and in the cases where it does something wrong, the result is easy to fix. it doesn't result in things quietly doing the wrong thing

• Criteria to ship
    * Overall small number of crates affected (<5%)
    * Known bugs result in "noisy" migration failures where things fail to compile
    * Not subtle changes in semantics that are likely to go unnoticed
sounds like those are met
yes
Where is that criteria listed?
Or is that something you just made up :blush:
lol I just wrote it ;) but I do recall we had some text t this effect in the RFC
we made it up last time
and yes we made up something similar last time we talked about this
Ok I was just going to say that 5% seems high.
https://rust-lang.github.io/rfcs/3085-edition-2021.html#metrics-for-a-successful-edition
in the RFC we said 10%, but I agree
I would probably actually want it to be 1% or something
(do we know the %?)
I remember it being quite small

Given that most non-trivial projects contains at least a handful of crates if not more, 5% failure means it's actually likely you'll see an error (assuming failure is equally likely across all crates)
we could actually do the math :)
sure, it depends a bit on what you consider 'affected'. in this case about half the cases were just issues with resolver = "2" with diesel and mime_guess, which were expected.
is that something that requires manual intervention?
if so, is it documented in the edition guide?
sounds like it's worth calling out
yes and yes. cargo even detects it and tells users about it
excellent :)

and remember that unlike any other crater run we do, the failures are not things that will just happen if people upgrade to a newer rust version. these are things people might run into if they decide to migrate to a new edition. which only happens if they feel like it.
This is true, but we do expect most people to upgrade, no?
so here's another question
(i.e., the subset of migrators is smaller than the subset of upgraders, but not by much)
looking at the list of known failures and things

tons of crates are not that actively maintained that they get upgraded directly as the edition is stabilized. and even if they do run into a problem. they can just stay on 2018 until it is fixed, in case something is really wrong.
how many of these would we want to fix for 1.57
there seem to be a few I'd like to fix

rylev said:

(i.e., the subset of migrators is smaller than the subset of upgraders, but not by much)

i don't think that's true at all. updating a rustc version affects all crates you depend on. upgrading to a new edition only your own crate.
maybe we can briefly categorize this list that way?
I'm adding things into https://hackmd.io/thUMCESvSMqxKDFkjs2ggA
most of the issues that are open are things that would probably stay open for ages. some are issues that were already around in the 2018 migrations. (e.g. fixing things multiple times in macros)
I agree that actively triaging them might make the decision even more clear
so you think the list of "worth fixing" is empty?
that's what I'd like to ascertain :)
the 'expands macro expressions' is a general problem that has been around for ages in many lints. i've been fixing some one by one. going to work on a more general fix this week.
what is #88115?
that ' applied multiple times' issue was around in the 2018 migration as well. there it'd insert multiple lifetimes: &'_ '_ '_ T
the <dyn BlahMissingGenerics>:: issue is annoying, but doesn't occur very often, and the issue is clear enough for the user and easy to fix.
(are we actually noting this triaging somewhere? i.e., if we think it's a blocker, 1.57 fix, or fix whenever)
I am noting this in the hackmd
but I was thinking
maybe we want to jump on jitsi?
and use a google spreadsheet?
@Mara it seems like you have a lot of context :)
I'd appreciate going systematically though
it'll make me feel like we've done our due diligence :P
google spreadsheet
uh, yeah, i have time in two minutes. one sec
https://meet.jit.si/Rust2021
let me know if you want me to join
https://hackmd.io/xltX-gYFRpO-2OHDAW9Sag?both
@Eric Huss feel free but not obligated :)

• Plan of record
    • Stabilize on nightly
    • Land documentation changes plus cargo updates
    • Further testing during beta period
      • Port compiler to new edition
      • Continue to categorize crater results and monitor issues
    • If no problems are found once compiler is ported
      • announce that 2021 is riding the trains
time to hit the r+ button :tada:

Bug fixes for two of the invalid prelude collision suggestions we saw:

  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88497
  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88496
• https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88501

Fix for the missing array_into_iter case:

  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88503
holy macarel
you're on a roll
:horse_racing: go @Mara go! :horse_racing:
let's see how many i can fix before i fall asleep

Bug fix for turbofish disappearing in prelude collision suggestion:

  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88504

Bug fix for <<dyn TooManyAngleBrackets>>::stufff:

  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88509

Fix for array_into_iter for lazy_static arrays:

  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88512
okay that's enough for today. time to sleep :zzz:
i think that were pretty much all edition issues that were not closure capture related ^^

I am pondering https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/88440:

I think that the resolution of "not machine actionable" is correct, but that does imply that if users ignore this, they may wind up with code that has subtle changes in semantics (though they will get a warning!)
I have to re-read our edition migration rules
we shouldn't ignore/silence it. but maybe we can warn without the invalid suggestion. but maybe the invalid suggestion is actually clearer than whatever alternative we could come up with
Don't we want things to break loudly in this case? We can't migrate their code properly so we break their code so they're forced to deal with the issue manually?
It seems like we never want the user to experience changed semantics if they run the migration so if we cannot migrate we almost have to break the user's code

rylev said:

Don't we want things to break loudly in this case? We can't migrate their code properly so we break their code so they're forced to deal with the issue manually?

yeah exactly
